title: 107_hr1061
content: The "Consumer Banking Services Costs Assessment Act of 2001" requires a survey of bank fees and services under Section 1002 of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System is required to conduct an annual survey of retail banking services and products offered by insured depository institutions and credit unions, including checking accounts, savings accounts, ATM transactions, electronic transactions, and credit cards. The survey must be representative by institution type, size, and location, and include data on fees and minimum balances. The survey conducted by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System includes data on checking and transaction accounts, such as fees for monthly and annual fees, minimum balances, check processing, printing fees, balance inquiries, teller fees, stop payment orders, nonsufficient funds, overdrafts, deposit items returned, and availability of low-cost accounts for consumers with low balances. The data on negotiable order of withdrawal accounts and savings accounts includes details such as monthly and annual fees, minimum balances, interest rates, check processing and printing fees, balance inquiry fees, teller fees, stop payment order fees, and nonsufficient fund fees. The data on automated teller machine transactions includes details such as annual and monthly fees, card fees, fees for withdrawals, deposits, transfers between accounts, and balance inquiries through institution-owned and other machines. Data on electronic transactions includes fees for withdrawals, deposits, transfers between accounts, balance inquiries, point-of-sale transactions, wire transfers, and payments made over the Internet. Credit card data includes application fees, annual and monthly fees, and interest rates for purchases. The curr_chunk discusses various fees and charges related to credit card accounts, including interest rates, finance charges, late payment fees, cash advance fees, balance transfer fees, over-the-credit-limit fees, foreign currency conversion fees, and other fees determined by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. Annual reporting to Congress on this information is required. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System prepares a report on survey results regarding retail banking services, including trends in cost and availability nationwide, in each state, and in metropolitan areas. The report includes data on fees, minimum balances, and differences between institutions based on type and size. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System submits an annual report to Congress on insured depository institutions and insured credit unions. A sunset provision in the Riegle-Neal Interstate Banking and Branching Efficiency Act of 1994 is repealed, and a provision in the Federal Reports Elimination and Sunset Act of 1995 is deemed nonapplicable. The Federal Reports Elimination and Sunset Act of 1995 does not apply to reports required under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989.
